exampleSentence.georgian: სერია II-ში, გარდამავალი ზმნების სუბიექტი ერგატივშია
exampleSentence.transliteration: seria II-shi, gardamavali zmnebis subiekt'i ergat'ivshia
exampleSentence.translation: In Series II, the subject of transitive verbs is in ergative case

vocabulary.notes: Grammatical case marking the subject of transitive verbs in past tense (Series II) and perfect tense (Series III)

exampleSentence.georgian: წარსულ დროში, გარდამავალი ზმნის ობიექტი აბსოლუტივშია
exampleSentence.transliteration: ts'arsul droshi, gardamavali zmnis obiekt'i absoluti'vshia
exampleSentence.translation: In past tense, the object of transitive verbs is in absolutive case

vocabulary.notes: Case marking that is identical to Nominative - used for intransitive subjects and transitive objects in Ergative-Absolutive alignment

exampleSentence.translation: Series I uses the nominative-accusative system

vocabulary.notes: Alignment system where subjects of both transitive and intransitive verbs are marked the same way (Nominative), and objects are marked differently

exampleSentence.georgian: სერია II და III იყენებენ ერგატივ-აბსოლუტივ სისტემას
exampleSentence.transliteration: seria II da III iq'eneben ergat'iv-absoluti'v sist'emas
exampleSentence.translation: Series II and III use the ergative-absolutive system

vocabulary.notes: Alignment system where intransitive subjects and transitive objects are marked the same (Absolutive), and transitive subjects are marked differently (Ergative)

exampleSentence.translation: Georgian language is characterized by split-ergativity

vocabulary.notes: The phenomenon where a language uses different alignment systems (Nominative-Accusative vs Ergative-Absolutive) depending on tense, aspect, or mood

exampleSentence.translation: In past tense, case shift occurs

vocabulary.notes: The systematic change in case marking when moving from Series I to Series II/III, particularly the shift of objects from Dative to Nominative/Absolutive

exampleSentence.georgian: ქართულში არის სამი სერია: I, II და III
exampleSentence.transliteration: kartulshi aris sami seria: I, II da III
exampleSentence.translation: In Georgian there are three series: I, II, and III

vocabulary.notes: Groups of verb screeves organized by Tense-Aspect-Mood features. Series I: Present/Future (imperfective). Series II: Aorist (perfective past). Series III: Perfect/Pluperfect (perfective).
Verbs that take a direct object. Only transitive verbs show the full case shift in Series II/III

exampleSentence.translation: The subject of intransitive verbs is always in nominative case

vocabulary.notes: Verbs that do not take a direct object. Intransitive verbs do not show case shift - their subjects remain in Nominative in all series

exampleSentence.georgian: აორისტი არის წარსული დრო სერია II-ში
exampleSentence.transliteration: aorist'i aris ts'arsuli dro seria II-shi
exampleSentence.translation: Aorist is the past tense in Series II

vocabulary.notes: A perfective past tense that forms part of Series II. Aorist triggers Ergative-Absolutive alignment for transitive verbs

exampleSentence.translation: Perfective aspect is a completed action

vocabulary.notes: Aspect indicating that an action is viewed as a complete whole. In Georgian, perfective aspect (Series II and III) triggers Ergative-Absolutive alignment

exampleSentence.translation: Imperfective aspect is a continuous action

vocabulary.notes: Aspect indicating that an action is ongoing, habitual, or not completed. In Georgian, imperfective aspect (Series I) uses Nominative-Accusative alignment

exampleSentence.georgian: გარდამავალ ზმნებში, სუბიექტი ერგატივშია წარსულ დროში
exampleSentence.transliteration: gardamaval zmnebshi, subiekt'i ergat'ivshia ts'arsul droshi
exampleSentence.translation: In transitive verbs, the subject is in ergative case in past tense

vocabulary.notes: The doer of the action in a sentence. Case marking of subjects differs based on alignment system and verb transitivity

exampleSentence.georgian: ობიექტის შემთხვევა იცვლება სერია I-დან სერია II-ში
exampleSentence.transliteration: obiekt'is shemtkheva itsvleba seria I-dan seria II-shi
exampleSentence.translation: The object's case changes from Series I to Series II

vocabulary.notes: The receiver of the action in a transitive sentence. Objects shift from Dative (Series I) to Nominative/Absolutive (Series II/III)
Common ergative case suffix added to many nouns in Series II/III transitive sentences. Marks the transitive subject in past/perfect tenses
